title: Darka
content:
Good morning,

I was wondering if anyone knew of a way to get hold of (buy, legally) Darka?  
 [http://www.kimeratype.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20101105143019/http:/www.kimeratype.com/ "http://www.kimeratype.com/")

(NB: It's a Flash site, so I can't get you any closer than that.)

I think it's a really lovely typeface and might be just the right thing for some work. However, I called FontShop per Kimera's instructions and they said they no longer work with Kimera. I sent an email to Kimera and no one responded. Kimera appears to have dropped off the face of the earth post 2006.

I am impressed with some of the work I see and I would love to buy Darka at the very least! Can anyone help?

Sincere thanks,

Keith
author: keithdvo

comments.content: There is a phone number for Gabrielle. I would try that. It's a very lovely blackletter style and worth the effort. I found pointers to both My Fonts and FontShop, but searches on both of those showed nothing.

There's a phone number on the website. Have you tried calling Gabriel directly?

[Will Powers](http://web.archive.org/web/20101105143019/http:/typophile.com/user/7891), in your neck of the woods just over in St Paul, might be able to put you in touch with him directly. I think he and Gabriel are still in contact.

Thank you, Guys!

I have avoided dialing the number in part because of the long distance cost, but perhaps that will be my only option now. (AT&T can have some really punitive rates at times.) I confess I am also a bit hesitant giving my information over the phone. (And Visa will charge me an additional fee for an out-of-country purchase.) Still, I suspect Kimera is most likely a very reputable company (if it still exists!).

In fact, I've been tempted to make a second post on purchases and trust. How does one know the reputable type companies. Clearly Adobe, LInotype, and generally I would assume companies recommended on this site….

kentlew, thank you for Will's name. I sent him an email asking if he was still in contact with Gabriel. Fingers crossed!

I'm certainly open to suggestions, because as Stephen notes, this is a really lovely blackletter. I love this man's work: it pays honor to the past while brining it into the present.

Keith
